subject: Bouncing a font idea off of you.
msgSnippet: One of the things that initially turned me off about Jerome was its treatment of #29, #31, #35 & #37.  They were merely rotated versions of each other!  At
messageBody:
One of the things that initially turned me off about Jerome was its
treatment of #29, #31, #35 & #37. They were merely rotated versions
of each other! At first, I thought this was ludicrous, but then I
discovered that it's a lot more difficult to connect with #35 & #37 in
the realm of fontdom. Giving them more standard connections (i.e.
Jerome) seems the logical thing to do, but in order to differentiate
them, I propose to render them in the same basic shape that Jerome
does, but with the loops in #35/#37 represented as perfectly circular,
while #29/#31 will be represented elliptically (and of course
distinctly so). What does everyone think about this?

What do you propose that I do about #38? Would an appropriate
solution be to serif it slightly (like an Omega)?

-A

One of the things that initially turned me off about Jerome was its
treatment of #29, #31, #35 & #37.  They were merely rotated versions
of each other!  At first, I thought this was ludicrous, but then I
discovered that it's a lot more difficult to connect with #35 & #37 in
the realm of fontdom.  Giving them more standard connections (i.e.
Jerome) seems the logical thing to do, but in order to differentiate
them, I propose to render them in the same basic shape that Jerome
does, but with the loops in #35/#37 represented as perfectly circular,
while #29/#31 will be represented elliptically (and of course
distinctly so).  What does everyone think about this?

What do you propose that I do about #38?  Would an appropriate
solution be to serif it slightly (like an Omega)?

-A
